Residents on three Manchester streets are furious after being told they will no longer be able to leave their bins outside their homes because waste lorries are having trouble navigating the narrow cul-de-sacs. 
Council bosses have told households on Cambridge Avenue, Lynwood Avenue and Granville Avenue in Whalley Range they will no longer be allowed to leave their bins in front of their houses and will have to lug them to the end of their streets. 
Town hall chiefs say bin wagon drivers have had problems reversing down the narrow avenues because there are too many parked cars, which they’re worried about damaging. 
Residents on all three avenues will, from February 8, have to take all bins to the junction with Clarendon Road. 
The changes will mean residents having to make the trip with up to four bins - blue, brown and green for recycling and grey for general waste. Peter Hamilton, Charles Frize, Ibrahin Dar, Daniel O'Sullivan, Steve Jones, Sajid Ahmed and Abdul Janjua are furious after being told they will no longer be able to leave their bins outside their homes (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Read More 
Residents say there are a number of disabled and elderly people living on the avenues who will struggle to move their bins so far. 
But the town hall says they can make alternative arrangements for those who need help. 
A letter has been sent to residents on the three avenues. 
It reads: “Owing to the narrowness of the streets and the number of parked cars, we have increasing concerns about the safety of accessing these streets with the large bin wagons. 
“Clearly, we cannot take risks in damaging people’s cars and for that reason we cannot continue to reverse bin waggons down these streets.” 
Grey bins for general waste were made 40 per cent smaller in Manchester last year as the city’s recycling push continued. 
Council bosses say the number of cars parked on the three Whalley Range avenues has caused a headache for bin men, but residents say there are no more than usual. Read More Thousands more Salford bins will now only be collected every THREE weeks 
One, who asked not to be named, said: “The wagons have been reversing down these avenues for years. There are no more cars than usual, I just don’t understand their reasoning, there is no issue. 
“What are we paying our council tax for? First they make the bins smaller, then this. And they didn’t even bother to consult us on it. 
“People don’t want to be dragging their bins to the main road every time.” 
The council’s executive member for neighbourhoods Nigel Murphy said: “We always endeavour to collect bins from as close to people’s properties as possible. In this case, a combination of the narrowness of these short cul-de-sacs and an increased number of parked cars means we can no longer safely reverse a bin lorry out of them without potential damage to residents’ vehicles or property or even the risk of danger to residents themselves. 
“While we recognise this is not ideal, we feel that asking residents to take their bins to the end of the street is the only viable option. If anybody will struggle physically to push their bins down these streets they can contact us to arrange an assisted collection.” Like us on Facebook
